channel.title: NYT > Climate and Environment
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: They Came From Outer Space. Now, They’re Going Into Hiding.
item.description: Rising temperatures in Antarctica are making meteorites sink out of view before researchers can collect them.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Kornei

item.title: PFAS ‘Forever Chemicals’ Are Pervasive in Water Worldwide, Study Finds
item.description: A global survey found harmful levels even in water samples taken far any obvious source of contamination.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:credit: Joshua A. Bickel/Associated Press
item.media:description: The study “sets off alarm bells,” one of the authors said.

item.title: There’s an Explosion of Plastic Waste. Big Companies Say ‘We’ve Got This.’
item.description: Big brands like Procter & Gamble and Nestlé say a new generation of plants will help them meet environmental goals, but the technology is struggling to deliver.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Recycled polypropylene pellets at a PureCycle Technologies plant in Ironton, Ohio.

item.title: Another A.I. Target: Food Waste
item.description: Artificial intelligence is peering into restaurant garbage pails and crunching grocery-store data to try to figure out how to send less uneaten food into dumpsters.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: The Challenge of Hiking Up Mount Whitney in California
item.description: Last July, a recently divorced writer who had found solace in hiking took on a towering challenge: Mount Whitney, the highest peak in the lower 48 states.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Lucy Wood
item.media:description: A hike up 14,494-foot Mount Whitney last summer brought beautiful moments like the early-morning light in Big Horn Sheep Park, as well as difficulties like unexpectedly snow-packed trails.

item.title: An Engineering Experiment to Cool the Earth
item.description: A new technology is attempting to brighten clouds and bounce some of the sun’s rays back into space.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold, Christopher Flavelle, Michael Simon Johnson, Eric Krupke, Luke Vander Ploeg, Rachelle Bonja, Patricia Willens, Rowan Niemisto, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Ian C. Bates for The New York Times
item.media:description: A spraying machine designed for cloud brightening on the flight deck of the Hornet, a decommissioned aircraft carrier that is now a museum in Alameda, Calif.

item.title: Her Art Is at Odds With Museums, and Museums Can’t Get Enough
item.description: Gala Porras-Kim has confronted the restitution of cultural artifacts and now — with melting Antarctic ice — climate change.
item.dc:creator: Karen Rosenberg
item.category: Museum of Contemporary Art Denver (MCA Denver)
item.media:credit: Victor Llorente for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gala Porras-Kim’s art can be described as a new variant of institutional critique. “How do we move from just prioritizing the material, when there are some things beyond the material that could be preserved better?” she said.

item.title: Richard Benedick, Negotiator of Landmark Ozone Treaty, Dies at 88
item.description: He played a key role in securing the Montreal Protocol, an international environmental pact to protect the ozone layer by reducing the use of certain chemicals.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel

item.title: Is Traveling by Train Always Cleaner than Flying? It’s Complicated.
item.description: The surprising carbon footprint of an Amtrak trip across America.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Hiroko Tabuchi/The New York Times

item.title: Michael Singer, Sculptor Who Used Nature as His Medium, Dies at 78
item.description: His work, on an increasingly large scale, attempted to highlight, and repair, the impact of human intervention on the landscape.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: Ford Slows Its Push Into Electric Vehicles
item.description: The automaker said it would delay new battery-powered models and shift its focus to hybrid cars, sales of which are rising fast.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.category: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks
item.media:credit: Sylvia Jarrus for The New York Times
item.media:description: The production line of the Ford Lightning F-150 electric pickup truck in Dearborn, Mich. The company said it would delay the introduction of new electric vehicle models.

item.title: Plan to Stash Pollution Beneath the Sea Could Save Money and Jobs
item.description: The Italian energy giant Eni sees future profits from collecting carbon dioxide and pumping it into natural gas fields that have been exhausted.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Maurizio Fiorino for The New York Times
item.media:description: This gas processing plant at Casalborsetti is the focus of the first phase of an ambitious plan to capture carbon dioxide and bury it under the sea.

item.title: Ocean Temperatures Suggest a Daunting 2024 Hurricane Season
item.description: An early forecast from one set of experts sees an above-average hurricane season that may rival the busiest years on record.
item.dc:creator: Judson Jones

item.title: Environmental Protection Agency Gives $20 Billion in ‘Green Bank’ Grants
item.description: The E.P.A. said the fund will spur a clean energy transition in overlooked communities. Republicans called it a “greendoggle.”
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Environmental Protection Agency headquarters in Washington. The agency plans to award grants ranging from $500 million to $6.9 billion to eight nonprofits that will loan the money to clean energy projects.

item.title: As Wildfires Grow Fiercer, Some Companies Look to Rebuild the Tree Supply Chain
item.description: As forests succumb to ever-fiercer wildfires, the federal government and some adventurous private companies are trying to resuscitate an industry.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis
item.category: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs
item.media:credit: Ian Allen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Saplings, grown at Mast’s Washington state nursery, are destined for replanting in the wild.

item.title: Global Forest Loss Remains High, Despite Recent Progress
item.description: Wildfires and agricultural expansion offset big gains in protecting tropical forests last year.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:credit: Victor R. Caivano/Associated Press
item.media:description: Burned forest in Fort Chipewyan, Alberta. Wildfires in Canada last year destroyed almost three times as much forest as in any other year.

item.title: Late Winter Storms Spare California From Drought Pain, for Now
item.description: A rush of precipitation lifted the state to its second straight year with above-average snowfall, though Gov. Gavin Newsom warned residents not to grow used to it.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: David Calvert for The New York Times
item.media:description: South Lake Tahoe was under a rare blizzard warning in early March.

item.title: To Slow Global Warming, Scientists Test Solar Geoengineering
item.description: A trial in California is testing a machine designed to reflect sunlight back into space. “All my colleagues hope that we never use these things,” one researcher said.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle and Ian C. Bates
item.media:description: A spraying machine designed for cloud brightening on the flight deck of the Hornet, a decommissioned aircraft carrier that is now a museum in Alameda, Calif.

item.title: How to Make Polluters Pay
item.description: A new Vermont bill would create a “climate superfund.”
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: The state of Vermont is one of several states in the Northeast that suffered from devastating floods last summer.

item.title: Is It a Blizzard? A Nor’easter? And What’s the Difference?
item.description: How to stay safe when the snow is coming down.
item.dc:creator: Camille Baker

item.title: Tesla’s Sales Drop, a Sign That Its Grip on the E.V. Market Is Slipping
item.description: Sales of the company’s electric cars dropped in the first three months of the year, even as other automakers sold more battery-powered vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing and Neal E. Boudette
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tesla’s relatively flat sales are the latest sign that the company’s dominance of the market for electric cars is slipping.

item.title: Why Is There So Much Plastic Food Packaging?
item.description: As governments impose limits on plastic food packaging, climate-friendlier alternatives are in the works. Here are some that might be coming to a grocery store near you.
item.dc:creator: Kim Severson

item.title: 5-Star Bird Houses for Picky but Precious Guests: Nesting Swiftlets
item.description: To lure swiftlets, whose saliva-built nests fetch high prices in China, people in Borneo compete to build them the most luxurious accommodations: safe, clean, dark and with pools for bathing.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock, Muktita Suhartono and Nyimas Laula
item.media:credit: Nyimas Laula for The New York Times
item.media:description: Not a prison nor a fortress, but a bird house on Borneo for swiftlets, whose nests fetch high prices in China.

item.title: The New Climate Tech
item.description: Ambitious projects are trying to engineer the atmosphere.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Francesca Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Iceland.

item.title: Can We Engineer Our Way Out of the Climate Crisis?
item.description: Blocking solar rays. Sucking carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. Ideas that sound like science fiction are now starting to become reality, raising concerns about safety.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.category: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs
item.media:credit: Francesca Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mammoth, a giant machine in Iceland that will pull planet-warming carbon dioxide out of the air.

item.title: Angry Farmers Are Reshaping Europe
item.description: Farm protests are changing not only Europe’s food system but also its politics, as the far right senses an opportunity.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Ivor Prickett
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Benoit Merlo’s organic farm in eastern France.

item.title: Is Guyana’s Oil a Blessing or a Curse?
item.description: More than any single country, Guyana demonstrates the struggle between the consequences of climate change and the lure of the oil economy.
item.dc:creator: Gaiutra Bahadur and Keisha Scarville
item.media:description: With the discovery of offshore oil, Guyana is now building a natural gas pipeline to bring the byproducts of oil production to a planned energy plant.

item.title: How Climate Change Is Changing Heatwaves
item.description: Climate change is making heat waves linger for longer stretches of time, exacerbating the effects of extreme temperatures.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:credit: Miguel Schincariol/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Scorching temperatures this month in São Paulo, Brazil.

item.title: New Pollution Rules Aim to Lift Sales of Electric Trucks
item.description: The latest in a string of ambitious climate regulations aims to clean up the heaviest polluters on the road. But truckers are worried.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport and Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A truck driver at Hight Logistics with one of the company’s electric trucks in their company’s lot.

item.title: ‘Arctic Ascent With Alex Honnold” Is as Anxiety-Inducing as It Gets
item.description: On “Arctic Ascent With Alex Honnold,” big-wall climbers set out to make history. Their tense conversations give a peek inside the interpersonal dynamics of those who regularly risk death.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam
item.category: Arctic Ascent With Alex Honnold (TV Program)

item.title: Harsh Mongolian Winter Leaves Over 5 Million Animals Dead
item.description: Mass death caused by a weather event known in Mongolia as dzud has devastated herds, leaving thousands of families short of food.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon, Khaliun Bayartsogt and Somini Sengupta
item.category: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
item.media:credit: Byambasuren Byamba-Ochir/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A pile of sheep and goat carcasses in Bayanmunkh, in Mongolia’s Khentii Province. Nearly six million livestock have died in Mongolia this winter because of the dzud weather phenomenon.

item.title: Having Trouble With Your Homeowners Insurance? Tell Us.
item.description: Bills are soaring. Insurance companies are struggling. We want to hear how it’s affecting you.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle and Mira Rojanasakul
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: A First Step Toward a Global Price on Carbon
item.description: A tax on ship emissions could have an impact on almost everything we buy
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni and Max Bearak
item.media:credit: Max Miechowski for The New York Times
item.media:description: A tax on ships’ emissions could have an impact on basically everything we buy.

item.title: Methane From Landfills Is a Big Driver of Climate Change, Study Says
item.description: Decades of buried trash is releasing methane, a powerful greenhouse gas, at higher rates than previously estimated, the researchers said.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Andri Tambunan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Landfills are the third-largest source of human-caused methane emissions, according to the Environmental Protection Agency.

item.title: Biden Administration Restores Protections Under the Endangered Species Act
item.description: The rules give federal officials more leeway to protect species in a changing climate. Industry groups are expected to sue.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:credit: Michael Walker/Alamy
item.media:description: A San Joaquin kit fox in the Carrizo Plain National Monument in California. The species has been on the endangered list since 1967.

item.title: The Last Coal-Fired Power Plants in New England Are to Close
item.description: The company that owns the Merrimack and Schiller stations in New Hampshire plans to turn them into solar farms and battery storage for offshore wind.
item.dc:creator: Minho Kim
item.media:credit: Gordon Chibroski/Portland Press Herald, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Schiller coal-fired power station in Portsmouth, N.H. In recent years, it had run only intermittently during peak periods.

item.title: A Simple New Technique Could Make Your Eggs More Humane
item.description: A system that determines the sex of chicks before they hatch eliminates the need to destroy young males.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Joel Saget/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Several European countries already use technology that can determine a chick’s sex before it hatches and have banned culling.

item.title: Kongjian Yu Has a Plan for Urban Flooding: ‘Sponge Cities’
item.description: A landscape architect in China has a surprising strategy to help manage surges of water from storms supercharged by climate change.
item.dc:creator: Richard Schiffman
item.media:credit: Mark Schiefelbein/Associated Press
item.media:description: Kongjian Yu at his office in Beijing. “We’ve been using the conventional drainage infrastructure for 200 years and we haven’t solved the flooding problem,” he said.

item.title: Jane Goodall Is More of a Dog Person, Actually
item.description: Dr. Goodall, who is best known for her work with chimpanzees, recently celebrated her forthcoming 90th birthday with as many dogs and explained why she isn’t slowing down.
item.dc:creator: Darren Incorvaia

item.title: Palisades Nuclear Plant in Michigan Plans to Reopen With $1.5 Billion Loan
item.description: The conditional loan from the Energy Department is part of a broad effort to revive the use of nuclear energy in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: John Madill/The Herald-Palladium, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A federal loan will help restart the Palisades nuclear plant in Covert Township, Mich., which closed in 2022.

item.title: London Boat Race Marred by High Levels of E. Coli in Thames
item.description: Rowers in the Oxford-Cambridge Boat Race this weekend have been warned of dangerously high levels of E. coli in the River Thames, the latest sign of England’s polluted waterways.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Boyers/Reuters
item.media:description: The Oxford women’s team during practice on Thursday on the River Thames.

item.title: Berkeley Will Repeal Its Landmark Ban on Natural Gas in New Homes
item.description: The decision, which came after a legal challenge, throws into question the fate of dozens of similar measures across the United States.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Ed Buziak/Alamy
item.media:description: Gas meters at an apartment building in Berkeley, Calif.

item.title: A Great Lakes Pipeline Tangles Politics in Two Battleground States
item.description: Line 5 crosses tribal lands, runs beneath the water and needs major upgrades. Opponents fear spills. Supporters envision jobs. Everyone sees a fight.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Halleck and Dionne Searcey
item.category: Bad River Band of the Lake Superior Tribe of Chippewa Indians
item.media:credit: Cydni Elledge for The New York Times
item.media:description: Enbridge’s Line 5 operations near the Straits of Mackinac.

item.title: Why the Solar Eclipse Will Not Leave People Without Power
item.description: Grid managers say they are well prepared to handle a sharp drop in the energy produced by solar panels as the eclipse darkens the sky in North America on April 8.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Solar panels produce electricity most during the very time that the eclipse will pass over the United States.

item.title: They Grow Your Berries and Peaches, but Often Lack One Item: Insurance
item.description: Farmers of fruits and vegetables say coverage has become unavailable or unaffordable as drought and floods increasingly threaten their crops.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Cooley
item.media:credit: Holly Lynton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bernie Smiarowski grows potatoes and strawberries on his farm in Hatfield, Mass. Barely half the land devoted to specialty crops like those was insured in 2022.

item.title: How Elon Musk Became ‘Kind of Pro-China’
item.description: Mr. Musk helped create China’s electric vehicle industry. But he is now facing challenges there as well as scrutiny in the West over his reliance on the country.
item.dc:creator: Mara Hvistendahl
item.media:credit: Aly Song/Reuters
item.media:description: Elon Musk, Tesla’s chief executive, dancing onstage during a delivery event for Tesla’s China-made Model 3 cars in Shanghai in 2020.

item.title: Tesla’s Pivot to China Saved Musk. It Also Binds Him to Beijing.
item.description: Tesla and China built a symbiotic relationship, with credits, workers and parts that made Mr. Musk ultrarich. Now, his reliance on the country may give Beijing leverage.
item.dc:creator: Mara Hvistendahl, Jack Ewing and John Liu
item.media:credit: Aly Song/Reuters
item.media:description: Elon Musk dancing in 2020 as his company, Tesla, unveiled the first cars made at its factory in Shanghai.

item.title: Orcas Are Considered One Species. Should They Be?
item.description: A new study suggests that two killer whale populations in the North Pacific are distinct enough to be considered separate species.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Louise Johns for The New York Times
item.media:description: A southern resident killer whale and its younger sister in waters off Washington state. Although the two types of orcas live in the eastern North Pacific, they have different diets: fish for the residents, marine mammals such as seals for Bigg’s whales.

item.title: Why Palm Oil Is Still a Big Problem
item.description: The ubiquitous ingredient contributes to the loss of tropical forests.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Unloading palm fruits at a collecting station in Gomantong, Sabah, Malaysia.

item.title: A New Law Would Remove Many Architectural Protections in Miami Beach
item.description: Lawmakers say preservationists held too much power over decisions on whether buildings should be demolished and what should be allowed to replace them.
item.dc:creator: Julia Echikson
item.media:credit: Moris Moreno for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Sherry Frontenac Hotel was built in 1947. The “saw-tooth” design of its two towers provide the side rooms maximum light and ocean views.

item.title: Saving Seals From a Sea of Plastic and Marine Garbage
item.description: Ocean Conservation Namibia is disentangling a record number of seals, while broadcasting the perils of marine debris in a largely feel good way.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley

item.title: Vacation Rentals: How to Make Your Stay Sustainable
item.description: Tips on finding a sustainable short-term rental, what you can do to conserve energy and getting involved in the community.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac
item.media:credit: Weston Wei
